newsitem.title: BOLIVIA: U.S. firm Airport Group wins Bolivian airport bid.
newsitem.headline: U.S. firm Airport Group wins Bolivian airport bid.

text.p: U.S. company Airport Group International has won a license to run Bolivia's three main airports for the next 25 years, government Secretary of Capitalization Edgar Saravia announced Friday.

Airport Group takes over La Paz's El Alto airport, Cochabamba's Jorge Wilstermann and Santa Cruz's Viru Viru in four months after beating Canada's YVR Airport Services and Spain's Aeropuertos Espanoles y Navegacion Aerea in Thursday's bid.
The winning bid gives the government a 20.8 percent share in revenue, compared to the 19.1 percent offered by YVR and 19.05 percent by the Spaniards.

Airport Group, which already runs 18 airports in the United States, Canada and Guam, is committed to investing $100 million to expand and improve the airport terminals to bring them up to the "class-B" standard of the International Air Transport Association, said Saravia.

The three airports privatized concentrate more than 80 percent of Bolivian air traffic and the government hopes that Viru Viru, with its location on flat land in the dead center of South America, will assume international importance.
Saravia said the Bolivian state plans to use the resources from the privatization to improve Bolivia's 34 other airports.
